content.title: Open Aortic Aneurysm Repair (OAR)
content.definition: Surgical replacement of an aneurysmal aortic segment with a prosthetic graft through direct surgical exposure, clamping, and reconstruction. The original treatment for abdominal aortic aneurysm, now compared against EVAR as definitive treatment options.

key_concepts.description: AAA ≥5.5cm (men) or ≥5.0cm (women); rapid growth (>1cm/year); symptomatic aneurysm; rupture; anatomy unsuitable for EVAR (short neck, severe iliac disease)

Transperitoneal (midline laparotomy) allows bilateral iliac and renal artery access; Retroperitoneal (left flank) reduces ileus, respiratory complications; choice based on anatomy and surgeon preference
Infrarenal (most common, safest); Suprarenal (if juxtarenal aneurysm - up to 30 min safe ischemia); Supraceliac (if pararenal). Higher clamp = higher risk (renal failure, visceral ischemia)
Tube graft (aorta-to-aorta) if iliac arteries normal; Bifurcated graft (aorta-to-iliacs or aorta-to-femorals) if iliac aneurysms/occlusive disease. Dacron standard, ePTFE alternative
Inferior mesenteric artery reimplanted if: dominant IMA (absent SMA collaterals), previous colectomy, poor backbleeding. Prevents left colon ischemia
Cold crystalloid or cold blood perfusion for suprarenal clamp; Limit warm ischemia time; Mannitol; Maintain adequate perfusion pressure
Sudden release of aortic clamp causes hypotension from vasodilation, washout of anaerobic metabolites, third-spacing. Gradual clamp release, volume loading, and vasopressors prepare for this
Elective open repair: 2-5% mortality; EVAR: 1-2% 30-day mortality but higher reintervention. Ruptured AAA: 40-50% mortality for those reaching OR
Cardiac (MI most common cause of death); Pulmonary; Renal failure; Colonic ischemia; Paraplegia (rare for infrarenal); Graft infection; Sexual dysfunction
OAR: higher perioperative mortality but durable; EVAR: lower early mortality but requires surveillance and more reinterventions. Long-term survival similar. Patient anatomy and fitness guide choice

content.statement: Open Aortic Aneurysm Repair (OAR) is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures Open-Aortic-Repair that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

learning_objectives: Understand indications for open AAA repair
Know surgical approaches and clamp positions
clinical_pearls: Infrarenal clamp is standard and safest
IMA reimplantation if: dominant vessel, prior colectomy, poor backbleeding
Cardiac event is #1 cause of perioperative death
Declamping hypotension - anticipate and prepare with volume/pressors
OAR has fewer reinterventions than EVAR long-term
Ruptured AAA: 40-50% mortality - patients who make it to OR still high risk
common_mistakes: Choosing OAR in patient suitable for EVAR without reason
